ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned about the mental and physical capabilities of human infants and animals. I also learned how humans and animals might not be so different from each other...
How babies and nonhuman animals process the world. To what extent they have the cognitive abilities of adult humans.
I learned about the connection between babies and animals and how much more intelligent both are.
Information about the cognitive abilities and new research into infants and animals.
I obtained an understanding of the foundational concepts of cognitive science and the way that cognitive science experiments are conducted
We learned how babies and some animals learn a sense of number and number systems, how they adopt language/communication systems, and how they develop moral systems and emotions.
I gained a greater understanding of the cognitive aspects of babies and animals.
human=animal, but also human>animal (in terms of language and some cognitive function)
I learned key studies and fundamental concepts in the field of cognitive science, relating to both human babies and animals.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: A strength is the live discussion session held each week. They provided much clarity and allowed for more stimulating thought about the different concepts. A weakness is that there wasn't too much discussion of the weekly problem sets that were assigned, so I never really knew if my answers were correct.
Not very much time learning with the professor - most learning occurred through the pre-recorded material. But the pre-recorded material was very engaging and the workload was low.

Strengths: the course itself is genius,  I found myself chatting about the class often and it is one of those classes that constantly comes up in conversation.
Weakness: the way in which the course is taught. We teach the class to ourselves the whole time and lectures are just q and as that can feel too long with no real learning accomplished.
I generally prefer courses with less of the grade weighted on exams- 80% is a bit high

weaknesses: discussion classes felt unproductive
strengths: lecture were engaging and informative

Sometimes I felt like it would've been better if the professor lectures during class rather than host two-hour discussion sections--that way we can ask questions as we're learning the material and we don't have to watch lectures AND do readings. However, I understand that it was a lot of lecture material so perhaps that wouldn't have been possible.

The course allows you to learn about a wide range of cognitive topics. I think it could have been improved with more of a focus on emerging research and theories in the field since cognitive science, especially under these domains, is a very new and rapidly developing area.

Discussions with Dr. Wynn and Ashley clarified any confusion on course content and allowed for further analysis of assigned readings/studies. Weekly online reading/lecture viewing was a bit heavy, but that's to be expected with online summer courses.

The strengths of this class were that it was able to communicate a large amount of information in a short amount of time and that every class was essentially a discussion section, allowing students to ask questions. However, the weaknesses were that the lectures were not recently recorded and were not captioned.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, I would definitely recommend this course to anyone, regardless if they're a psychology major. The course material is super interesting and is not too difficult to understand.
Absolutely. It was one of those courses with a low workload but a lot of learning.
If it was taught differently, absolutely! The way it is now? Sure but with less enthusiasm. The material is still fascinating but its use of lecture time leaves something to be desired.
I learned a lot of interesting and surprising stuff about baby brains and would definitely recommend!
Yes, interesting and informative

I would recommend it if they are truly interested in the subject matter. All the readings and lectures are very excellent and detailed but if you do not have an interest in the topics presented it would be very rough.

Dr. Wynn's humor and personal anecdotes always make for an entertaining session. Both instructors were super flexible with timing. Content was engaging and has sparked further curiosity in infantile studies. So, yes...
Yes, this is a great class to learn the basics of cognitive science and about the young of our own species as well as others.
